thread.title: Right place, right time for Blue Jays' Jonathan Diaz
thread.title_full: Right place, right time for Blue Jays' Jonathan Diaz

title: Right place, right time for Blue Jays' Jonathan Diaz
text:
Report an error BALTIMORE - 
Leaving no stone unturned, the Blue Jays called up utility infielder Jonathan Diaz so they will be able to have enough bodies to field a team through the coming days. 
The plan, once the Jays clinched the AL East division championship, was to rest the regular players and go with backups for one day. 
In the Jays’ case, dealing with a doubleheader Wednesday, it meant they used backups in the second game of the doubleheader and were planning to rest the regulars on Thursday as well. 
“It turned out to be a good day for not playing,” manager John Gibbons said of Tuesday. In addition to the rainout, both the New York Yankees and Kansas City Royals lost. 
“We brought up an extra player, move guys around if we need an extra body. If we clinch, guys need a break and we’re covered at every spot. After we clinch, the guys are going to need a day, they’ve earned that.” 
Diaz had been working out in Dunedin at the Jays instructional camp just in case. 
“He was coming anyway,” Gibbons said of Diaz, who was drafted by the Blue Jays in 2006. “He’s the perfect guy, last couple of years he’s been up and down, let him come in and enjoy it too.” 
Diaz is thrilled to be part of it. 
“I guess I came at the right moment for the celebration so I’m just happy to be here,” Diaz said before the game. “I was ecstatic (to get the call). I’ve been in this organization for nine out of 10 years and there’s a lot going on right now and it’s exciting and I’m just happy to be here and do whatever it takes to help these guys out.” 
A DIFFERENT LOOK 
In the nightcap, with the division clinched, Gibbons kept to his word and didn’t use any of his regulars. 
The batting order was the following: 
1. Dalton Pompey , CF;
